Award.AwardTitle: Methods for Dynamic Network Identification with Application to the Control of Smart Buildings

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
A dynamic network consists of interacting dynamic sub-systems. Such networks occur in many domains: living cells, financial markets, the Internet and the power grid are some examples. Heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HAVC) systems in buildings can also be modeled through dynamic networks since each room's climate depends on that of nearby spaces. Knowledge of such dynamic network models is essential to design and deploy control strategies devoted to the improvement of energy efficiency and occupant comfort. Yet, in practice the structure and dynamics of these networks are either unknown or imprecisely known. For instance, information on the thermal interaction among rooms is difficult to obtain from laws of physics due to the complexity of the physical processes involved. The goal of this project is to formulate algorithms for the identification of dynamic sparse network models from measured data. The research results will support the study of advanced controls for HVAC systems to reduce their energy use and to provide demand-side flexibility to the power grid. Since buildings consume 75% of the nation's electricity, improvement of energy efficiency through smart building control systems will contribute to the sustainability of the nation's energy system.

Although 'dynamic system identification' is a well-developed field, the field of identification of dynamic networks is not at all well-developed. Traditional dynamic system identification techniques cannot exploit the inherent sparseness of the network identification problem, while traditional machine learning techniques are mostly applicable to only static networks. In this project we combine ideas from traditional dynamic system identification, L1 optimization for sparse vector recovery (from compressed sensing), and graphical modeling from machine learning to address the challenges in dynamic network identification. If successful, the research will (1) provide fundamental contribution to the nascent field of dynamic network identification through new algorithms, and (2) enable speedy deployment of 'smart building' technologies in commercial buildings. In addition, the project will support a number of educational innovations for attracting students from under-represented groups to engineering and generating excitement about engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A dynamic network consists of interacting dynamic sub-systems. Such networks occur in many domains, such as living cells, financial markets, the Internet and the power grid. Heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HAVC) systems in large commercial buildings is another important domain in which dynamic networks play a role because of the interaction between various equipment and processes.

Models of dynamic networks in HVAC systems are essential to design advanced model-based control algorithms for indoor climate control. Prior research has shown such control algorithms can reduce energy use in buildings significantly at low cost. Since buildings account for 75% of the electricity consumed in the United States, such control systems can reduce the energy cost and carbon footprint of the nation. Yet, the structure and dynamics of these networks are either unknown or imprecisely known, creating a bottleneck in designing such control systems.

The goal of this project was to develop techniques to learn models of dynamic networks from easily available measurements (data), especially for networks that are relevant to control of HVAC systems in buildings. An additional requirement was that the techniques have to be autonomous. While there is half-a-century of research on learning models from data, existing methods are not autonomous since they require re-tuning by human experts every time they are applied on a new data set. The networks relevant to HVAC systems change slowly over time due to changes in the building’s equipment, structure, and usage. Thus, a data-driven technique needs to produce a good answer when new data is fed into it without requiring a human expert to re-tune it. Only then it can be used as part of a control system that can automatically adapt to changes in the building.

The project was quite successful in developing such autonomous data-driven techniques for learning dynamic networks for HVAC systems. Unlike prior art, the techniques developed in this project provide guarantees on properties of the models learned, a feature that was lacking in previous research. The techniques we developed were validated against data collected from multiple real buildings. Comparison with methods already available in the literature demonstrated not only the key advantage of our methods over the competition, that is, autonomy, but also higher prediction accuracy. These results were published in highly reputed journals and presented in peer-reviewed international conferences.

The data-driven learning techniques developed in this project were then used to develop a self-learning control system for intelligent control of HVAC system. Through simulation on a digital twin of a building, we were able to show that the control system can reduce energy use HVAC systems by more than 20% without any change in equipment. Experimental verification of the control system is planned for the future.

Apart from research results, the project contributed significantly to graduate and undergraduate education, professional development of the students, and to the recruitment of female students engineering. The project partially supported four PhD students and two MS students. One of the Ph.D. students is a woman. All the graduate students published high impact journal articles and presented conference papers on research supported by this project. In the process, they learned effective written and oral communication skills. They also learned specialized software skills – such as relational database management - needed by a 21st century workforce. Two of these graduate students found employment in national labs and in the building automation industry, contributing to the scientific workforce of the nation.

One of the female PhD students supported by this project interned at Mitsubishi Electric Research Laboratory during Spring 2020 through a supplementary funding to this project. She gained valuable experience about industry through this internship, and according to her it contributed hugely to her professional development.

The project has also contributed to technology transfer to the building automation industry. We are currently in discussions with a building automation system vendor for potential commercialization of the HVAC control technology we are developing that utilizes the data-driven learning methods that came out of this project.
